ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Professor Solodow has provided me with a wonderful knowledge of Ancient Greek historiography in this course. Moreover, my writing, close reading skills, and distillation of large themes have all improved greatly.

Familiarity with historiographical questions, and questions about the origins of modern historiography. An attention to the literary side of apparently historical texts. An introduction to Greek history and geography.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the only weakness would be to not include the fragments from historians, which Professor Solodow has already identified as not being necessary. as for strengths, I think the course was perfectly structured in its length for each historian; I always felt that we spent just enough time with every historian. Moreover, while at first I was not as excited about the biblical readings, I felt them to be extremely useful. It was very interesting to see the biblical texts placed next to Herodotus, Thucydides, and Polybius; therefore I think their inclusion was definitely a strength. The major strength and defining feature of this course was Professor Solodow, who is a very engaging, accessible, and thoughtful Professor.

Great introduction to Greek historians. I think the essays and exams were of appropriate difficulty and length. Perhaps in terms of the syllabus the following class should read the entirety of the first book of Herodotus.  I particularly enjoyed the time we spent on Acts, and think we benefited from all the class time we devoted to it. I was also very interested in the topic of the Hellenization of the Jewish world. Perhaps optional secondary readings should be made available to those who want more historical context etc.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I think any student interested in ancient history, and more specifically historiography would benefit from this course!
Yesif they were interested in these texts.
